subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Earnings and updates from Samsung Electronics, Canon and Newcrest Mining
content:
AUSTRALIA

AMP Capital (AMP AT)
- Some of the Co.’s largest customers are urging the Co. to come clean regarding malpractices at its AUD 28bln corporate super business. (The Australian)

BHP (BHP AT)
- EMR Capital is said to show interest in Co. Cerro Colorado copper mine. (The Australian)

Brambles (BXB AT)
- Co. 9-month sales revenue from cont. ops rose 5% to AUD 4.2bln. (Newswires)

ClearView Wealth (CVW AT)
- Sony Life did not make a takeover bid prior to yesterday’s deadline. (Newswires)

GPT Group (GPT AT)
- Co. affirms FFO growth target at 3% for FY18. (Newswires)

Healthscope (HSO AT)
- Co. received unsolicited offer valued at AUD 2.36 per share vs. last close AUD 2.03. (Newswires)

Iress (IRE AT)
- Bounty Holdings reportedly made an approach for the Co. (Newswires)

Newcrest Mining (NCM AT)
- Co. Q3 gold output 576k ozs vs. Exp. 583k ozs, Prev. 599k ozs a year ago. (Newswires)
- Co. Q3 copper output 18.9k tonnes vs. Prev. 22.1k tonnes a year ago.

Scentre Group (SCG AT)

St Barbara (SBM AT)
- Co. is said to be seeking deals in North America. (AFR)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Co. Q3 Coles sales rose 0.3% Y/Y to AUD 9.05bln. (Newswires)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Iron ore fell 1.3%.
- WTI crude rose 0.5%.

Other News
- Australian Treasurer Morrison said the budget on course to return to balance by 2020/21, also confirmed government has dropped planned levy hike on Medicare. (Newswires)
- Australia’s federal budget is to unveil income tax cut plan which will begin with small reductions and will be phased over 10 years. (AFR)

 

JAPAN

Canon (7751 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 57.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 55.1bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Kansai Electric (9503 JT)
- Seven & I (3382 JT) 7-Eleven stores are to switch to Kansai Electric service at 3000 stores. (Newswires)

KDDI (9433 JT)
- Co. may reports FY 17/18 oper. profit JPY 1.0tln. (Nikkei)

Line (3938 JT)
- Co. Q1 net loss JPY 1.38bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 1.44bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 48.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 38.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mazda (7261 JT)
- Co. expected to report FY 17/18 oper. profit fell 20% to JPY 110bln. (Nikkei)

NTT DoCoMo (9437 JT)
- Co. may report FY 17/18 oper. profit JPY 980bln vs. guidance JPY 960bln. (Nikkei)

Oriental Land (4661 JT)
- Co. may report FY 17/18 oper. profit fell Y/Y to JPY 110bln. (Nikkei)

Tokyo Electron (8035 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 204.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 115.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Daewoo Engineering & Construction (047040 KS)
- Co. Q1 net KRW 111.6bln vs. Exp. KRW 93.0bln. (Newswires)

Hanwha (000880 KS)
- Samsung is to offload Hanwha General stake to Bain Capital. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. is said to aim for Chinese sales of 900k vehicles for this year. (Newswires)

LG International (001120 KS)
- Co. Q1 net loss KRW 87.5bln vs. Exp. net profit KRW 16.1bln. (Newswires)

Lotte Corp (004990 KS)
- Co. is to sell stores in China to Wumei for KRW 256bln. (Newswires)

Naver (035420 KS)
- Co. Q1 net KRW 165.2bln vs. Exp. KRW 209.8bln, rev. KRW 1.31tln vs. Exp. KRW 1.27tln. (Newswires)

Samsung C&T Corp (028260 KS)
- Co. Q1 net KRW 398.6bln, oper. profit KRW 209.2bln vs. Exp. KRW 167.5bln. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. Q1 oper. profit KRW 15.64tln vs. prelim. KRW 15.60tln, rev. KRW 60.56tln vs. prelim. KRW 60.00tln. (Newswires)
- Co. is to offload Hanwha General stake to Bain Capital.

Auto related
- South Korea Transport Ministry said that 4 automakers including Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) and Kia Motors (00270 KS) are to conduct a recall of more than 230,000 vehicles due to faulty parts. (Yonhap)

Other News
- North and South Korea are said to be expected to discuss a gradual removal of weapons from the demilitarized zone. In addition, there were also reports that South Korean President Moon may visit Pyongyang later in the year. (Newswires)

- South Korean GDP Growth (Q1 P) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.8%)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
UK

UK House of Lords defeated PM May's government on legislation over Brexit regarding the adoption of wide-ranging law-making powers post-Brexit. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond said UK is at the beginning of talks with EU regarding the finance sector post-Brexit. (Newswires)


FX

DXY edged a bit further above 91.000 handle USD No change in the overall buy Dollar trend, and against almost all currency rivals, as elevated US Treasury yields continue to provide the Greenback a prop and carry premium. The index marginally extended gains to just over 91.200, but still needs to clear resistance around 91.500 to form a more solid base and challenge January peaks (circa 92.600). AUDNZD Fresh lows vs the USD just over 0.7550 and 0.7065 respectively as the antipodeans succumbed to further selling pressure in ANZAC holiday-thinned market conditions. CHF/EUR/JPY The Franc extended losses vs the Greenback and EUR towards 0.9850 resistance and the 1.2000 old SNB floor in wake of a bleak Swiss ZEW survey, while EURUSD slipped a bit further below 1.2200 to a fresh cycle base just under a key Fib level (1.2173), but not quite low enough to trip stops reportedly set around 1.2170. USDJPY got a pip or so close to 109.50 supply and its nearest Fib (109.65), but also retraced as both held in. USDCAD gradually pared back a lot of the gains after hitting 1.2900 during US trade and ahead of BoC’s Governor Poloz and Wilkins appearance scheduled after-market. Comments from Canada’s Freeland over NAFTA did not add much of a reaction. Sterling also yielding a bit more ground to the buoyant Buck with Cable slipping below 1.3950, but not quite revisiting this week’s low that aligns with the upper end of a 1.3920-1.3890 chart support area. NOK The Krona weakened within a 9.6575-9.7165 range amidst calls from Norway’s opposition party to reverse the Norges Bank’s inflation target cut from 2.5% to 2%, even though the Government rejected the request. TRY Not much love for the Lira amidst broad EM currency depreciation vs the USD as the TRY fell to around 4.1000 even though the CBRT hiked its LLW by ¼ point more than expected to 13.50%.

Canada Foreign Minister Freeland expects more negotiations on NAFTA auto rules to take place later and repeated Canada expects to have permanent exemptions from US steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

Turkish Late Liquidity Window Rate (Apr) 13.5% vs. Exp. 13.25% (Prev. 12.75%). (Newswires)
Turkish One-Week Repo Rate (Apr) 8.00% vs. Exp. 8.00% (Prev. 8.00%)
Turkish Overnight Borrowing Rate (Apr) 9.25% vs. Exp. 9.25% (Prev. 9.25%)
Turkish Overnight Lending Rate (Apr) 7.25% vs. Exp. 7.25% (Prev. 7.25%)


COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (20 Apr) 2.170M vs. Exp. -1.600M (Prev. -1.071M). (Newswires)
US crude production up 0.44% at 10.586mln bpd


GEOPOLITICAL

US Non-Proliferation Envoy Ford said the US is not looking to reopen or renegotiate the Joint Comprehensive Plan Of Action Iran deal, but instead fix its flaws with a supplementary agreement. (Newswires)


US

Moody's affirmed US at AAA rating and maintained stable outlook. Moody's said would consider changing US rating and outlook if it concluded in the approaching years that policymakers lack capability to respond decisively to mitigate adverse fiscal dynamics in medium-term. (Newswires)

US official noted that priorities for US at April 27th NATO meeting are financial burden sharing with members mainly Germany, as well as underscoring Russian aggression and Syria regarding alliances' talks in considering Europe southern frontier. (Newswires)

Notable Earnings
AT&T (T) Q2 Adj EPS USD 0.85 vs. Exp. USD 0.87, rev. USD 38bln vs. Exp. USD 39.31bln.
Boeing Co (BA) Q1 Non-GAAP EPS USD 3.64 vs. Exp. USD 2.58, revenue USD 23.4bln vs. Exp. USD 22.24bln.
Facebook (FB) Q1 EPS USD 1.69 vs. Exp. USD 1.35, rev. USD 11.97bln vs. Exp. USD 11.41bln raises buyback by USD 9bln.
Las Vegas Sands (LVS) Q1 EPS USD 1.04 vs. Exp. USD 0.85, Revenue USD 3.58bln vs. Exp. USD 3.38bln.
Qualcomm Inc (QCOM) Q2 Adj EPS USD 0.80 vs. Exp. USD 0.70, revenue USD 5.2bln vs. Exp. USD 5.19bln.
Visa Inc (V) Q2 EPS USD 1.11 vs. Exp. USD 1.02, revenue USD 5.10bln vs. Exp. USD 4.8bln.


MARKET RECAP

The Emini S&P 500 was mostly contained within the 2620-2640 range. There was some weakness at the cash open, following in the vein of Tuesday trade. But in later trade, there was upside, helping the Emini push above 2640 temporarily, though a batch of headlines regarding AG Sessions brought some caution once again, and indices slipped back into ranges. Pre-market earnings from Boeing (BA) managed to support the Mini Dow, but the gains struggled to hold, and the selling overpowered the strong earnings from the largest Dow component. Stock specifics, the SPX was led by Norfolk Southern (NSC) beating on both the top and bottom end, also supported by comments of a promising outlook and raising the annual repurchase programme by USD 1.5bln. Hampering the SPX on Wednesday Trade, Trade Advisor (TRVG) underperforming following earnings from competitor Trivago (TRGO) who lowered its next forecasts. NDX was led by Texas Instrumentals (TXN) following strong earnings and guidance, which then led to a string of price target increases from names like Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley. The other end of the scale, saw Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Checkpoint Software (CHKP). WYNN was led lower following weaker than expected revenue from Wynn Macau, and CHKP weaker as it trimmed its 2018 outlook, which saw Deutsche, Morgan Stanley and Cowen, trim company price targets also. DJI the outperformer of the trio boosted by strong Boeing (BA) earnings as it equates to roughly 10% of the index, however General Electric (GE) limiting the gains as the largest underperformer today as its first annual shareholder meeting went underway, where it was met with protests from both employees and shareholders about recent underperformance, where shareholders called for an ousting of some directors, and voted for a smaller board with three new members, and also voted down six proposals from shareholders. In M&A news, the narrative continued for Shire (SHPG) after confirmation it received a revised offer from Takeda for USD 30.30/shr. Sources suggested after market yesterday, a preliminary announcement for the USD 65bln deal was expected today, but nothing was seen, further GSK ruled out purchasing the pharmaceutical name. Also, Comcast (CMCSA) made a superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN), implying a value of GBP 22.0bln. Later, Sky (SKY LN) told holders to take no action regarding the offer; Sky are withdrawing their recommendation for the 21st Century Fox (FOX) offer. On smaller scale M&A sources voiced that Kroger (KR) is considering a bid for Supervalu (SVU), but this was unconfirmed, elsewhere Promedica, Welltower (WELL) are in a bid to acquire Quality Care Properties (QCP) for around USD 20/shr. SPX +0.18% at 2639, NDX 0.08% at 6513, DJI +0.24% at 24082.

Today’s auction of 5yr notes saw a stops-through by 0.1bps while the yield was the highest since September 2018. Directs took the largest portion since July 2014 whilst dealers and indirects saw coverage below recent averages. Most of the action was concentrated in the long-end of the curve as investors reallocated assets into long-term debt which pushed the 10yr and 30yr higher by c.4bps. The 30yr yield has touched a 2-month high in the session and extended gains above 3.2150 and settled just below that level. 5s10s, 5s30s and 2s10,2s30 spread both widened by c.2bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-02+.

US MARKET WRAP 25 April 2018: Market rangy ahead of ECB rate decision
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks higher, USD higher, treasuries lower, oil higher.
* REAR-VIEW: Boeing earnings, Turkey interest rate decision, US not looking to renegotiate/reopen JCPOA.
* AHEAD: after-market; BoC’s Poloz; Visa, Facebook earnings. Thursday; ECB, Riksbank rate decisions, earnings from Amazon, Microsoft, AbbVie, Intel.

*GEOPOLITICAL: A US official said that the agenda for the 24th April NAFTA meeting includes financial burden sharing, and ahead of Germany Chancellor Merkel’s visit to the US on Friday, the US official singled-out the nation for “financial burden sharing” on defence. Elsewhere, the official said other topics will include Syria, and “Russian aggression.” The official dodged a question on whether the likely next US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will be in attendance. Latest on Iran, the US Non- Proliferation Envoy Ford said the US is not looking to reopen or renegotiate the Joint Comprehensive Plan Of Action Iran deal, but a supplementary agreement.

*TRADE WARS: On the NAFTA front newsflow was thin, however updates came from Canada Foreign Minister Freeland who expects more negotiations on NAFTA auto rules to take place later on Wednesday. She also repeated that Canada expects to have permanent exemptions from US steel and aluminium tariff and highlighted the issue over tariffs is separate from NAFTA tall the US position is currently unclear.

*ECB SPEAK: Attention is on tomorrow’s ECB meeting (full preview here). The central bank is unanimously expected to leave its three key rates unchanged. Ultimately, this week’s press conference is set to offer little in the way of fireworks with June/July touted as a more opportune time for the ECB to unveil their next stage of major policy announcements. Draghi will likely make some reference to the recent softness in data but ultimately maintain that risks to economic growth are ‘broadly balanced. Before then, ECB's Vasiliauskas (Hawkish) appeared more confident that it is now time to 'transition' from QE, warning that a closure of bond buying should not be abrupt. ECB's Mersch (Hawkish) echoed words from a letter released on March 21st repeating that his confidence on inflation has moved higher recently.

*TURKEY INTEREST RATE DECISION: The central bank kept its weekly repo rate (8.00%), its overnight lending rate (9.25%) and its overnight borrowing rate (7.25%) unchanged  as expected, but lifted its late liquidity window rate more than anticipated - 75bps hike to 13.50% (Exp. 13.25%, 50bps hike). The central bank attributed its decision to much higher than anticipated oil prices, and Q1 solid economic activity which was mostly driven by solid consumer spending.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.18% at 2639, NDX 0.08% at 6513, DJI +0.24% at 24082 SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals:  +0.30%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.22%, Energy: +0.66%, Financials: -0.31%, Health Care: +0.13%, Industrials: +0.03%, Materials:+0.28%, Technology: -0.28%, Telecoms: +0.55%, Utilities: -0.06%.

The S&P 500 Emini was mostly contained within the 2620-2640 range, and moving sideways. There was some weakness at the cash open, following in the vein of Tuesday trade. But in later trade, there was upside, helping the Emini push above 2640 temporarily, though a batch of headlines regarding AG Sessions brought some caution once again, and indices slipped back into ranges. Hampering the SPX on Wednesday Trade, Trade Advisor (TRVG) underperforming following earnings from competitor Trivago (TRGO) who lowered its next forecasts. NDX was led by Texas Instrumentals (TXN) following strong earnings and guidance, which then led to a string of price target increases from names like Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley. The other end of the scale, saw Wynn Resorts (WYNN) and Checkpoint Software (CHKP). WYNN was led lower following weaker than expected revenue from Wynn Macau, and CHKP weaker as it trimmed its 2018 outlook, which saw Deutsche, Morgan Stanley and Cowen, trim company price targets also. DJI the outperformer of the trio boosted by strong Boeing (BA) earnings as it equates to roughly 10% of the index, however General Electric (GE) limiting the gains as the largest underperformer today as its first annual shareholder meeting went underway, where it was met with protests from both employees and shareholders about recent underperformance, where shareholders called for an ousting of some directors, and voted for a smaller board with three new members, and also voted down six proposals from shareholders. In M&A news, the narrative continued for Shire (SHPG) after confirmation it received a revised offer from Takeda for USD 30.30/shr. Sources suggested after market yesterday, a preliminary announcement for the USD 65bln deal was expected today, but nothing was seen, further GSK ruled out purchasing the pharmaceutical name. Also, Comcast (CMCSA) made a superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN), implying a value of GBP 22.0bln. Later, Sky (SKY LN) told holders to take no action regarding the offer; Sky are withdrawing their recommendation for the 21st Century Fox (FOX) offer. On smaller scale M&A sources voiced that Kroger (KR) is considering a bid for Supervalu (SVU), but this was unconfirmed, elsewhere Promedica, Welltower (WELL) are in a bid to acquire Quality Care Properties (QCP) for around USD 20/shr.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle up 35 cents at USD 68.05/bbl, Brent futures settle up 14 cents at USD 74.00/bbl. Oil has pulled back from 2014 highs on Wednesday and remained contained within a range of approx. a buck throughout Wednesday and only briefly extending the move to the downside following the release of the DoE’s inventory data where the  headline crude showed un unexpected build (crude stocks 2.170M vs. Exp. -1.600M, cushing stocks +0.459mln vs. Prev. -1.115M, distillate stocks -2.611mln vs. Exp. -0.807mln, gasoline stocks +0.840mln vs. Exp. -0.995mln, refining utilisation -1.6% vs. Exp. -0.3%). In fundamental news, Iraq southern exports were averaging 3.5mln bpd in April so far (in March exports were said to run at 3.453mln bpd). Crude did recover the post-DoE losses and in later trade when US equities turned flat crude had some upside and was lingering at the top end of the range.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-02+.  Today’s auction of 5yr notes saw a stops-through by 0.1bps while the yield was the highest since September 2018. Directs took the largest portion since July 2014 whilst dealers and indirects saw coverage below recent averages. Most of the action was concentrated in the long-end of the curve as investors reallocated assets into long-term debt which pushed the 10yr and 30yr higher by c.4bps. The 30yr yield has touched a 2-month high in the session and extended gains above 3.2150 and settled just below that level. 5s10s, 5s30s and 2s10,2s30 spread both widened by c.2bps.

* FOREX: DXY edges a bit further above 91.000 handle USD No change in the overall buy Dollar trend, and against almost all currency rivals, as elevated US Treasury yields continue to provide the Greenback a prop and carry premium. The index marginally extended gains to just over 91.200, but still needs to clear resistance around 91.500 to form a more solid base and challenge January peaks (circa 92.600). CHF/EUR/JPY The Franc extended losses vs the Greenback and EUR towards 0.9850 resistance and the 1.2000 old SNB floor in wake of a bleak Swiss ZEW survey, while EURUSD slipped a bit further below 1.2200 to a fresh cycle base just under a key Fib level (1.2173), but not quite low enough to trip stops reportedly set around 1.2170. USDJPY got a pip or so close to 109.50 supply and its nearest Fib (109.65), but also retraced as both held in. USDCAD gradually pared back a lot of the gains after hitting 1.2900 during US trade and ahead of BoC’s Governor Poloz and Wilkins appearance scheduled after-market. Comments from Canada’s Freeland over NAFTA did not add much of a reaction. Sterling also yielding a bit more ground to the buoyant Buck with Cable slipping below 1.3950, but not quite revisiting this week’s low that aligns with the upper end of a 1.3920-1.3890 chart support area. NOK The Krona weakened within a 9.6575-9.7165 range amidst calls from Norway’s opposition party to reverse the Norges Bank’s inflation target cut from 2.5% to 2%, even though the Government rejected the request. TRY Not much love for the Lira amidst broad EM currency depreciation vs the USD as the TRY fell to around 4.1000 even though the CBRT hiked its LLW by ¼ point more than expected to 13.50%.

* RIKSBANK: The central bank is expected to keep the repo rate unchanged at 0.50% on Thursday. TD Securities argues that the market is pricing a dovish outcome at the April meeting, with focus falling mostly on what will be said on the size of its first rate hike, which has not been subject of public discussions yet. Some are expecting the Riksbank to tweak its current guidance after weakness in recent inflation data, which only hinted at mild price pressures building in the economy. For the full preview click here.

WYNN was led lower following weaker than expected revenue from Wynn Macau, and CHKP weaker as it trimmed its 2018 outlook, which saw Deutsche, Morgan Stanley and Cowen, trim company price targets also. DJI the outperformer of the trio boosted by strong Boeing (BA) earnings as it equates to roughly 10% of the index, however General Electric (GE) limiting the gains as the largest underperformer today as its first annual shareholder meeting went underway, where it was met with protests from both employees and shareholders about recent underperformance, where shareholders called for an ousting of some directors, and voted for a smaller board with three new members, and also voted down six proposals from shareholders. In M&A news, the narrative continued for Shire (SHPG) after confirmation it received a revised offer from Takeda for USD 30.30/shr. Sources suggested after market yesterday, a preliminary announcement for the USD 65bln deal was expected today, but nothing was seen, further GSK ruled out purchasing the pharmaceutical name. Also, Comcast (CMCSA) made a superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN), implying a value of GBP 22.0bln. Later, Sky (SKY LN) told holders to take no action regarding the offer; Sky are withdrawing their recommendation for the 21st Century Fox (FOX) offer. On smaller scale M&A sources voiced that Kroger (KR) is considering a bid for Supervalu (SVU), but this was unconfirmed, elsewhere Promedica, Welltower (WELL) are in a bid to acquire Quality Care Properties (QCP) for around USD 20/shr.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle up 35 cents at USD 68.05/bbl, Brent futures settle up 14 cents at USD 74.00/bbl. Oil has pulled back from 2014 highs on Wednesday and remained contained within a range of approx. a buck throughout Wednesday and only briefly extending the move to the downside following the release of the DoE’s inventory data where the  headline crude showed un unexpected build (crude stocks 2.170M vs. Exp. -1.600M, cushing stocks +0.459mln vs. Prev. -1.115M, distillate stocks -2.611mln vs. Exp. -0.807mln, gasoline stocks +0.840mln vs. Exp. -0.995mln, refining utilisation -1.6% vs. Exp. -0.3%). In fundamental news, Iraq southern exports were averaging 3.5mln bpd in April so far (in March exports were said to run at 3.453mln bpd). Crude did recover the post-DoE losses and in later trade when US equities turned flat crude had some upside and was lingering at the top end of the range.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 8 ticks lower at 119-02+.  Today’s auction of 5yr notes saw a stops-through by 0.1bps while the yield was the highest since September 2018. Directs took the largest portion since July 2014 whilst dealers and indirects saw coverage below recent averages. Most of the action was concentrated in the long-end of the curve as investors reallocated assets into long-term debt which pushed the 10yr and 30yr higher by c.4bps. The 30yr yield has touched a 2-month high in the session and extended gains above 3.2150 and settled just below that level. 5s10s, 5s30s and 2s10,2s30 spread both widened by c.2bps.

The index marginally extended gains to just over 91.200, but still needs to clear resistance around 91.500 to form a more solid base and challenge January peaks (circa 92.600). USDCAD gradually pared back a lot of the gains after hitting 1.2900 during US trade and ahead of BoC’s Governor Poloz and Wilkins appearance scheduled after-market. Comments from Canada’s Freeland over NAFTA did not add much of a reaction. Sterling also yielding a bit more ground to the buoyant Buck with Cable slipping below 1.3950, but not quite revisiting this week’s low that aligns with the upper end of a 1.3920-1.3890 chart support area. NOK The Krona weakened within a 9.6575-9.7165 range amidst calls from Norway’s opposition party to reverse the Norges Bank’s inflation target cut from 2.5% to 2%, even though the Government rejected the request. PRIMER: Riksbank's rate decision due at 0830BST/0230EDT on 26 April
content:
• EXPECTATIONS: The central bank is expected to keep the repo rate unchanged at 0.50% on Thursday. TD Securities argues that the market is pricing a dovish outcome at the April meeting, with focus falling mostly on what will be said on the size of its first rate hike, which has not been subject of public discussions yet. Some are expecting the Riksbank to tweak its current guidance after weakness in recent inflation data, which only hinted at mild price pressures building in the economy.
  • INFLATION: in Q1, the central bank had pencilled in a rate of inflation around 1.7%, but the Q1 data came in at 1.5% in January, and remained at that level. Growth forecasts may also be revised lower, as business surveys continued to indicate softer economic conditions with a 7% drop in house prices in the March-August period weighing on the narrative.
  • OUTLOOK: Analysts at Capital Economics are confident that rate rises will still be forthcoming in 2018: “The Riksbank’s previous guidance was consistent with either two interest rate increases of around 10bps in July and September or a 25bp rise in September,” CapEco says. Analysts at Nordea, however, sees the first-rate hike coming slightly later (in Q4 2019) and expects the repo rate to be at -0.25% by the end of 2019, and argue that the Riksbank will most likely move in synchronisation with the ECB. 
  • MARKET REACTION: The Riskbank’s previous forecasts were based on the krona being relatively unchanged, however, since the last meeting (14/Feb) it has weakened, with EURSEK moving from 9.9042 to around 10.42). Barclays believes that if the Riksbank kept the rate path unchanged, it would signal some normalisation in H2 2018, and that give some support to the SEK. TD Securities suggests that a dovish market reaction will likely be seen if the Riksbank hinted at initial rate hikes between 10-12bps, while a more hawkish response would come in the event of a 25bps rate hikes signal.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US USD 35bln 5-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
ISSUANCE: US Treasury will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73blnin 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts.

5-YEAR PREVIEW: While current 5s trade fair on asset swap vs old 5s, as well as on the curve vs 2s and 10s, analysts at SocGen says that the 5-year sector has not been adequately set up for the auction from a relative value perspective, and will likely require concession going into the auction. The bank also notes the weak performance of the sector at recent auctions to be a negative, while also pointing to recent dealer positioning (dealers raise holdings of 3-6yr Treasuries, and are now long to the tune of $17.8bln – highest YTD).

  • Mattel (MAT) – Spin Masters is suing the co. over infringing on Bakugan Patents. (Newswires)
  • Monsanto (MON) – The co. announced it is launching the first product which deactivates a controversial weed killer inside spraying tools after it has been used. (Newswires)

  • Walmart (WMT) / American Electric Power (AEP)- The two have reached an agreement over the settlement for PSO's proposed Wind Catcher Energy Connection project. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Comcast (CMCSA) – The co. made a superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN), implying a value of GBP 22.0bln. Later, Sky (SKY LN) has told holders to take no action regarding the offer; Sky are withdrawing their recommendation for the 21st Century Fox (FOX) offer. (Newswires)
  • Costco (COST) – The warehouse retailer increased its quarterly dividend from USD 0.50/shr to USD 0.57/shr, payable May 25th to shareholders of record as of May 11th. (CNBC)

  • Micron (MU) – The tech co. will expand production in 10nm DRAM chips in Taiwan. (DigiTimes)
  • Shire (SHPG) – The co. confirmed to have received a revised offer from Takeda for USD 30.30/shr and 0.839 new shares. A preliminary announcement for the deal for USD 65bln is expected today. GSK ruled out buying the co. (Newswires)

  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – CEO notes the Boston project is not for sale, which is to be launched in mid-2019. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Phillips 66 Partners (PSXP) – The oil co. is forming a joint venture with Andeavor (ANDV) and Buckeye Partner (BPL), aimed at developing an open access terminal in Texas. The co. is entering in a partnership with West Texas over crude transportation from the Gray Oak Pipeline. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 25th April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Treasury yields continue rise putting pressure on European bourses
  • Oil prices consolidate after Tuesdays highs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, the Turkish rate decision, DoEs and a slew of speakers
  •  

ASIA

Asian stocks traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the broad weakness on Wall St amid rising US yields, in which the Nasdaq 100 underperformed with losses of over 2% and industrials led the DJIA lower after Caterpillar suggested that Q1 could be the apex for the year. Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) and KOSPI (-0.6%) were lower with participants also digesting earnings releases, while Takeda was among the worst performers in Japan after the Co. further sweetened its offer in pursuit of Shire. ASX and NZX were shut for ANZAC Day, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-1.0%) conformed to the downbeat tone after the PBoC skipped open market operations which resulted to a net daily drain of CNY 150bln, However, the losses in the mainland were contained amid continued chatter regarding further RRR cuts and as the previously announced cut took effect from today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful and have failed to benefit from the broad risk averse tone as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 710bln in the belly to super-long end, while USTs were choppy overnight with early pressure seen after the US 10yr yield continued to test the 3.000% level which it had earlier reclaimed for the 1st time since January 2014.

China researcher noted that deflation in China is possible as soon as Q4 this year and added that further reductions in RRR are expected, while there were also reports that a Chinese official sees large room for RRR reductions and sees it lowered by between 600-800bps in 3 years. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 150bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3066 (Prev. 6.3229) (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Vasiliauskas (Hawkish) is more confident that it is time to 'transition' from QE, adds closure of bond buying should not be abrupt. (Newswires)

ECB's Mersch (Hawkish) says that his confidence on inflation has moved higher recently. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

EU is said to be ready to offer UK a better trade deal if it chooses to remain in the customs union, according to an EU official. (Newswires)

UK's Brexit Minister Davis says he does not expect an extension of the customs union. (Newswires)

Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said they are in intensive NAFTA talks and noted good progress is being made on autos but the issue is complex. Freeland also commented after meeting with US Trade Representative Lighthizer that creative ideas by the US in regards to autos has helped progress discussions, while she added discussions will continue on Wednesday and that they are ready to respond to fresh proposals. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are seeing a lacklustre start following on from the sentiment seen yesterday on Wall Street and overnight during Asia-Pac trade. In terms of stock specifics, Shire (+0.2%) shares have been supported after recommending Takeda’s revised GBP 46bln takeover offer to its shareholders. In the earnings scope, markets have seen positive results from Kering, (6.4%) and Credit Suisse (+3.3%) with negative reports from Mediaset (-0.8%). Significant news later in the session from Comcast (CMCSA) whom make a superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN), implying a value of GBP 22.0bln

FX

DXY

The Greenback continues to piggy-back rising US Treasury yields after a relatively brief pause for breath as bond bears and bulls tussled for supremacy around the 3% mark in 10s. A more decisive break above has given the Dollar further impetus and the index has reclaimed 91.000+ status as a result, with fair resistance around 91.526 back on the radar ahead of 91.751 and a few more upside chart levels before early 2018 highs.

AUD/NZD

Both extending recent losses vs the Usd and now clearly down through round number supports (0.7600 and 0.7100 respectively), albeit with the markets bereft of depth in terms of volume and potential local dip-buyers given the ANZAC market holiday. However, the cross is back up near 1.0700 again to the relative benefit of the Aud over the Kiwi.

EUR/JPY/CHF

The renowned safe-havens are not deriving any real support, or much from the latest decline in global equity markets against the more compelling Usd ascent, mainly on the aforementioned ratchet up in US rates, but also perhaps amidst some early month-end positioning as rebalancing models point to net Dollar demand. Eur/Usd is pivoting 1.2200 where huge option expiries roll off on ECB day tomorrow (3+ bn), with Fib support around 1.2173 still underpinning the pair, but the upside capped ahead of 1.2250. Usd/Jpy has carved out a fresh multi-month top circa 109.25 after a brief dip below 109.00 and is back above the 100 DMA at 108.98 eyeing offers at 109.50 before a major fib at 109.65. Usd/Chf remains above 0.9800 and Eur/Chf is rebounding towards 1.2000 again with the Franc hardly helped by a sharp deterioration in ZEW’s Swiss Investor Sentiment index.

GBP/CAD 

Holding up better than major counterparts, though still weaker vs the Usd as Cable straddles 1.3950 and the Loonie 1.2850. Some independent positives for the Pound and Cad via latest Brexit and NAFTA reports indicating progress towards deals on transition and tri-party trade deals.  Note, BoC’s Poloz and Wilkins are due to speak later.

FIXED INCOME

Some respite for core bonds, but not before bears pounced to push debt futures down to fresh lows, while UST yields climbed more convincingly above the round number levels that had been resisting further advances. Bunds and Gilts extended losses to 31 and 32 ticks respectively at 157.45 and 120.73, while the equivalent 10 year T-note only stopped half a tick below 119-00 level as the corresponding yield approached 3.02%. Charts are all flashing red for futures, with market contacts highlighting a break below Tuesday’s base for the benchmark UST contract and potential stops targeting 118-29, then 118-15 and ultimately 117-27. For Bunds the next/nearest downside tech targets are 157.46-43, latter yesterday’s Eurex low, while Gilt sellers have a couple of ‘strong’ objectives in sight at 120.69 and 120.48.

COMMODITIES

In commodities, oil has pulled back from Q4 2014 highs and remains flat on the day as the bullish market was slowed by US inventories increasing by 1.1mln barrels as according to API and traders taking profits following highs hit on Tuesday. Gold is currently seen around five week lows amid currency effects and rising treasury yields. Aluminium also maintained its recent slide due to the aforementioned effects as well as the Rusal sanctions announcement on Monday, with a fall noted for the 5th session in a row.

Libya's oil output at the Waha oil field said to be back up to 300k bpd. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: Turkey Central Bank monetary policy decision to be released around 1200 BST on 25 April 2018
content:
• Turkey central bank rate decisions will be published at 1200 on Wednesday 25 April 2018.
  • EXPECTATIONS: The central bank is expected to keep its weekly repo rate unchanged at 8.00%, it’s overnight lending rate unchanged at 9.25%, its overnight borrowing rate unchanged at 7.25%, but is expected to lift its late liquidity window rate by 50bps to 13.25%. “The outlook for inflation has worsened due to the sharp fall in the value of the lira to record lows against the US dollar and the euro,” says Rabobank, which expects the liquidity window to be raised by as much as 100bps. “Much higher than previously anticipated oil prices and robust economic activity in Q1 - driven by solid consumer spending - are further valid arguments to expect Governor Cetinkaya to tighten monetary policy.”
  • POLITICS: The recent announcement of early elections by President Erdogan is said to give policymakers more room for manoeuvre, Rabo says, while recent comments from officials indicate that there might not be much political fallout from a rate hike.
  • TRY PRICE ACTION: TD Securities says even a 50bps hike would be “mildly positive” for the TRY, and USDTRY may fall between 0.50% and 1.00% on such news. “However, we doubt whether this would be enough to put the lira onto a stable or even appreciating trend in the medium-term. A failure to hike the liquidity window rate on Wednesday would be taken negatively by the markets - we would expect USDTRY to move up by about 1%,” TD says. Rabo, meanwhile, believes anything less than a 100bps hike would be insufficient to support TRY sentiment in the long term.

subject: Fixed Income: first lines of support and resistance breached
content: Some respite for core bonds, but not before bears pounced to push debt futures down to fresh lows, while UST yields climbed more convincingly above the round number levels that had been resisting further advances. Bunds and Gilts extended losses to 28 and 26 ticks respectively at 157.48 and 120.79, while the equivalent 10 year T-note only stopped 1+ tick short of the 119-00 level as the corresponding yield approached 3.02%. Charts are all flashing red for futures, with market contacts highlighting a break below Tuesday’s base for the benchmark UST contract and potential stops targeting 118-29, then 118-15 and ultimately 117-27. For Bunds the next/nearest downside tech targets are 157.46-43, latter yesterday’s Eurex low, while Gilt sellers have a couple of ‘strong’ objectives in sight at 120.69 and 120.48.

Short Sterling strip mildly steeper, Gilt leads soft
content: Minor front end outperformance along the UK STIR curve again, and pre-Liffe open omens for bonds suggest an initial/early markdown from Tuesday’s 121.05 close that looks odds-on to breach 121.00 as Bunds retreat below par (to 157.54, -22 ticks vs +12 ticks at best) amidst broadly upbeat if not outright hawkish ECB rhetoric. In terms of UK-specific or independent drivers there is nothing major scheduled or to report aside from an apparent carrot from the EU dangling better trade terms if the country remains in the customs union post-Brexit.

content: A tentatively firmer Eurex open for the 10 year German benchmark, acknowledging another Wall Street set-back late yesterday that spilled over to Asia-Pacific equities overnight and is expected to weigh on EU cash bourses when they resume trading today. However, the range is very tight between 157.78-88 vs Tuesday’s 157.76 close as US Treasuries remain defensive amidst yields pressed up against multi-year and headline grabbing highs. A very light docket on Wednesday will leave Eurozone markets looking for some/any inspiration from a trio of scheduled ECB speakers, but the prospect of much in the way of fresh policy guidance appears slim ahead of April’s meeting tomorrow.

subject: DAILY EU EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
25th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the broad weakness on Wall St amid rising US yields, in which the Nasdaq 100 underperformed with losses of over 2% and industrials led the DJIA lower after Caterpillar suggested that Q1 could be the apex for the year. Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) and KOSPI (-0.9%) were lower with participants also digesting earnings releases, while Takeda was among the worst performers in Japan after the Co. further sweetened its offer in pursuit of Shire. Elsewhere, ASX and NZX were shut for ANZAC Day, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.9%) conformed to the downbeat tone after the PBoC skipped open market operations which resulted to a net daily drain of CNY 150bln, However, the losses in the mainland were contained amid continued chatter regarding further RRR cuts and as the previously announced cut took effect from today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful and have failed to benefit from the broad risk averse tone as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 710bln in the belly to super-long end, while USTs were choppy overnight with early pressure seen after the US 10yr yield continued to test the 3.000% level which it had earlier reclaimed for the 1st time since January 2014.

* EQUITIES: SPX -1.36% at 2634, NDX -2.10% at 6509, DJI -1.77% at 24017 SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals:  -1.59%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.61%, Energy: -1.18%, Financials: -0.64%, Health Care: -0.88%, Industrials: -2.59%, Materials: -2.81%, Technology: -2.46%, Telecoms: +0.92%, Utilities: +0.56%.

There wasn’t a single specific catalyst for the stock slide on Tuesday, however, a collection of reasons applied pressure, leaving a risk-off taste in the mouth of traders. Worries resurfaced as the US 10-year yield crossed 3%, while the 2-year yield rose above 2.50%. Others cited concerns in the tech sector (AAPL fifth red day on concerns over iPhone demand, while GOOGL weighed after earnings, FAANG’s weak); others cited geopolitical uncertainties. The S&P 500 Emini was consolidating beneath 2700 pre-market, but not even decent numbers from Caterpillar (which lent some premarket strength to the Dow mini) could keep indices bid, and the grind lower was gradual yet persistent, accelerating in the latter part of the session, before basing around 2620.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the broad weakness on Wall St amid rising US yields
content:
Asian stocks traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the broad weakness on Wall St amid rising US yields

  • EU is said to be ready to offer UK a better trade deal if it chooses to remain in the customs union, according to an EU official
  • Looking ahead, highlights include the Turkish rate decision, DoEs and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asian stocks traded negative across the board as the region followed suit from the broad weakness on Wall St amid rising US yields, in which the Nasdaq 100 underperformed with losses of over 2% and industrials led the DJIA lower after Caterpillar suggested that Q1 could be the apex for the year. Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) and KOSPI (-0.9%) were lower with participants also digesting earnings releases, while Takeda was among the worst performers in Japan after the Co. further sweetened its offer in pursuit of Shire. ASX and NZX were shut for ANZAC Day, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (-0.9%) conformed to the downbeat tone after the PBoC skipped open market operations which resulted to a net daily drain of CNY 150bln, However, the losses in the mainland were contained amid continued chatter regarding further RRR cuts and as the previously announced cut took effect from today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful and have failed to benefit from the broad risk averse tone as well as the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 710bln in the belly to super-long end, while USTs were choppy overnight with early pressure seen after the US 10yr yield continued to test the 3.000% level which it had earlier reclaimed for the 1st time since January 2014.

China researcher noted that deflation in China is possible as soon as Q4 this year and added that further reductions in RRR are expected, while there were also reports that a Chinese official sees large room for RRR reductions and sees it lowered by between 600-800bps in 3 years. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net drain of CNY 150bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3066 (Prev. 6.3229)

UK/EU

EU is said to be ready to offer UK a better trade deal if it chooses to remain in the customs union, according to an EU official. (Newswires)

Italy's M5S leader Di Maio leader sees potential for negotiations with PD while he also noted the idea of a centre-right coalition has passed. (Newswires)

FX

Price action was kept rangebound amid a lack of data releases and market closures in the region. Nonetheless, the greenback attempted to nurse some of the prior session’s losses which saw a mild pullback in EUR/USD and GBP/USD, while USD/JPY reclaimed the 109.00 level. Elsewhere, AUD and NZD are subdued as participants were away for ANZAC Day, with AUD/USD pressured after it slipped below the 0.7600 handle while NZD/USD broke 0.7100 to the downside.
 

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were little changed overnight with WTI crude futures below USD 68/bbl following yesterday’s pullback and as the latest API inventory report provided no support given that headline crude stockpiles showed a surprise build. In addition, President Trump remained vague regarding the Iran nuclear deal and suggested that he was still undecided on whether to extend the agreement. Elsewhere, gold was kept subdued by a mild recovery in the greenback, while copper lacked demand amid a broad risk averse tone.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (20 Apr) 1.099M vs. Exp. -2.000M (Prev. -1.047M). (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump stated that nobody knows what he is going to do regarding Iran deal on May 12th, while Trump and French President Macron both believe Iran should not hold a Nuclear Weapon. Furthermore, Macron stated he wants to work on a new deal with Iran and the deal can be added to but should not be torn apart, while he also noted that President Trump’s concerns can be taken aboard. (Newswires)

US

There was an extraordinary amount of attention on 10-year yields temporarily breaching the 3.00% handle for the first time in four years, as the curve steepened, which also saw yields on 2s above 2.50% at one point. Traders were attributing the rise in yields to the notion that the Fed hikes will take an ‘autopilot’ approach (as was hinted by the Fed’s Williams over the weekend) as well as the increased size of issuance out of the US Treasury, which will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73bln in 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts. Today’s auction of 2s saw a tail of 0.5bps, while the yield at auction was the highest since 2008. The internals weren’t particularly bright, with cover beneath recent averages and direct takedown slightly higher than recent averages. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle unchanged at 119-10+.

Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said they are in intensive NAFTA talks and noted good progress is being made on autos but the issue is complex. Freeland also commented after meeting with US Trade Representative Lighthizer that creative ideas by the US in regards to autos has helped progress discussions, while she added discussions will continue on Wednesday and that they are ready to respond to fresh proposals. (Newswires)
